results.title: Wives' tales
results.creator_credit: Claire Forster and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
280 families were affected by the deployment of the 7th and 8th battalion with INTERFET (UN Sanctioned International Force in East Timor). For the women and families left behind, there was a pressing need for group support. Shying away from a tag such as “the army wives club,” Patti-Jane Gould established the P.I.T. crew - Partners In Timor. The women of this support network speak candidly of the impact their partners departure has had on them and their children, how it feels to say goodbye, their fears, and how they adjust when life returns to “normal.” Army personnel share their fears and thoughts too and how their lives have changed since Timor. Finally, we share an emotional reunion on the docks. Introduced by Lieutenant General Peter Cosgrove.

results.title: A Track winding back
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
This documentary is based on a true story written by school teacher Carolyn Landon about bushman, Daryl Tonkin and his life and memories of Jackson’s Track in West Gippsland, Victoria. It is a story of love and tragedy, of an Aboriginal community living and working harmoniously with white people in the timber industry in the forest area of Jackson’s Track established by Daryl and his brother Harry during the 1930s. It tells of Daryl’s feud with his family when he decided to live with an Aboriginal woman, the dramatic kidnapping of this woman by his brother, Daryl’s life with the Aboriginal community and the eventual bull-dozing of the camp in the 1960s to appease local Christian groups resulting in the break-up and dispersal of the almost 100 people living at the camp. Daryl talks of himself as being at one with the Aboriginal way of life, a true bushman, who saw his life neither primitive nor of poverty and hardship, but as being his preferred way of life. Includes interviews with two of his nine children, re-enactments, stills and archival footage, and excerpts from the film “Rose against the odds”. Contains some b&w images.

results.title: The Cape crusade
results.creator_credit: Helen Grasswill and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Noel Pearson, Aboriginal lawyer and Cape York adviser, and his brother Gerhardt Pearson, Cape York leader, together and along with several key business people, philanthropists and the corporate world are attempting to change the social disintegration within the Cape York Aboriginal communities. This program explores the establishment of the Indigenous Enterprise Partnerships, a concept and strategy initiated by Noel Pearson, comprising of four private business entities - Westpac, Myer Foundation, Boston Consultancy and Bodyshop - and other leaders in the business world, along with Aboriginal leaders to provide employment and education to the remote indigenous communities and instigate social change especially amongst the younger generation. Disillusioned with Government bureaucracy and the welfare system, Noel and Gerhardt are committed to change, believing that to overcome the unemployment, alcoholism, gambling, illicit drug use, family violence and child abuse, change has to come from within the Aboriginal community itself. “Australian story” presents some of the early successes resulting from the partnership and includes interviews with Ann Sherry (Westpac), Colin Carter (Boston Consultancy), Noel Pearson and Gerhardt Pearson. Hosted by Caroline Jones.

results.title: Bridge over Myall Creek
results.creator_credit: Brigid Donovan, Caitlin Shea, Helen Gasswill, John Millard, Margaret Parker, Samantha Butler, Vanessa Gorman, Wendy Page and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
Caroline Jones introduces this episode of “Australian story” which looks at personal reconciliation in action as demonstrated by the relationship between Sue Blacklock and Beulah Adams, descendants of victim and perpetrator in the 1838 Myall Creek massacre. Researching into her family history, Beulah Adams discovered her great uncle was one of the perpetrators in a massacre that saw 28 First Nations people murdered.
Beulah talks candidly about her reaction to the news, and her experience at meeting Sue Blacklock - descendant of one of the only two people to survive the massacre - at a conference on reconciliation convened by Reverend John Brown. Another descendant of the murderers, Des Blake, talks about his experience at attending the Memorial’s opening at Myall Creek in 2002, and how the experience has changed his life since then.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Brigid Donovan, Caitlin Shea, Helen Gasswill, John Millard, Margaret Parker, Samantha Butler, Vanessa Gorman, Wendy Page and Australian Broadcasting Corporation

results.title: Australian story
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian story (Television program)”.
From the ABC television series “Australian Story” comes this compilation of five moving portraits of five very different Australians. Common to all five though is that they are battlers in their own way, overcoming adversity and hardship to live life as best they can. “The Big ‘A’” is about former Prime Minister’s wife Hazel Hawke speaking about her struggle with Alzheimer’s disease. “A Man for all seasons” is the story of revered rugby coach Wayne Bennett. “Boots and all” is about the discovery of a wonderful opera singer in a local shoe-repair shop - Peter Brocklehurst. “About a boy” is the story of young cricket enthusiast Dan Halloran, who grew up with his mother having a mental illness. “On the mountain top” is about Victoria Friend and her survival of a plane crash in remote country Australia.

results.title: Australian Story: Man For All Seasons: Wayne Bennett
results.creator_credit: Vanessa Gorman and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
This is Wayne Bennett’s story, a story of successes and failures, family, good times, challenging times, but most of all, about his passion for the Brisbane Broncos and helping them win more Grand Finals in his 20 years of coaching than any other club in Australian rugby league history. Introduced by Caroline Jones.
Broadcast on ABC TV on 6 May 1999. Reporters/producers include Ben Cheshire, Carolyn Davies, Brigid Donovan, Helen Grasswill, John Millard, Wendy Page.

results.title: Prisoner
results.creator_credit: Marie Trevor and Reg Grundy Productions
results.brief_description: Created by Reg Watson and screening a total of 692 episodes between 1979 and 1986, “Prisoner” was one of the first television series to tackle issues such as rape, homosexuality and violence. It did this through the relationships between a cross section of women and the women who work around them at the Wentworth Detention Centre. This groundbreaking serial funded by the Grundy Organisation was screened in countries throughout the world and was remade in Germany and the U.K. The complete title of the series overseas was “Prisoner: Cell block H”. PLEASE NOTE: the dates recorded in entries pertain to copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

constellations_other.name: Nadia Tass
constellations_other.description: Comedic and cult classics take centre stage in Nadia Tass' career.

results.description: Created by Reg Watson and screening a total of 692 episodes between 1979 and 1986, Prisoner was one of the first television series to tackle issues such as sexul assault, homosexuality and violence. It did this through the relationships between a cross-section of women and the women who work around them at the Wentworth Detention Centre. This groundbreaking serial, funded by the Grundy Organisation, was screened in countries throughout the world and was remade in Germany and the U.K. The complete title of the series overseas was Prisoner: Cell block H.

results.title: Prisoner: the terrorist siege [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Marie Trevor and Reg Grundy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
Ep. 550 (dir. Steve Mann, wri. Fay Rousseaux): Prisoners and guards find themselves banded together when Wentworth is taken over by terrorists hired to release Bellinger. Police try to negotiate amidst the claim that hostages will be executed on the hour unless their demands are met. “Ep. 551” (dir. Chris Adshead, wri. James Simmonds): The women look to Top Dog Myra Desmond (Anne Phelan) for a plan but it eventuates that she is to choose the next victim. Bellinger learns she is to be taken out if they cannot escape and Reynolds calls in Special Operations when she learns of the ultimatum. “Ep. 552” (dir. Chris Adshead, wri. Coral Drouyn): Julie makes it to the phone and someone else is killed on the hour. The Freak is taken hostage as the terrorists make their escape. The women come to terms with their losses once the terrorists have departed. “Ep. 536” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Coral Drouyn): This bonus episode features flashbacks from previous episodes - Chrissie Latham’s attack on Frank, reminiscences of Warden Vera, The Freak plying Lizzie with liquor for information, Bea Smith coming down on Lyn Warner (Kerry Armstrong) then Max, and her final showdown with The Freak. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

results.title: Prisoner: the end [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Marie Trevor and Reg Grundy Productions
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
Ep. 600 (dir. Steve Mann, wri. Ian Smith): Top Dog Lou Kelly (Louise Siversen) takes control of the prison and unleashes a reign of bashings, execution and intimidation. The episode culminates in an orchestrated fight to the death between The Freak (Maggie Kirkpatrick) and Rita Connors (Glenda Linscott). “Ep. 601” (dir. Kendal Flanagan, wri. Alister Webb): The siege is over and there are repercussions for ringleader Lou. Will anyone break the prisoners code of silence? The search is on for a new Top Dog. “Ep. 691” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Quincy McQuade): Concludes the storyline of the relationship between supporting characters Kath and Merle. Rumours spread of Rita’s cancer as well as concern at her purported friendship with The Freak. “Ep. 692” (dir. Sean Nash, wri. Marie Trevor, Ian Smith): In the climatic final episode Rita carries out the robbery planned in collaboration with The Freak. Retrieving the money appears hard though as Rita is captured and placed under close observation. Each section of episodes are introduced by Peter McTighe who explains what has transpired in the missing instalments. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.

results.title: Prisoner: the early years [DVD]
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “Prisoner [Cell block H]”.
166 (dirs. Rod Hardy, Juliana Focht, prod. Philip East, wri. Alistair Sharp): Top Dog Bea Smith (Val Lehman) leads 6 of her fellow prisoners through an escape tunnel during a pantomime. Terror mounts when the tunnel collapses; there will be fatalities. There’s disgruntlement amongst prison staff regarding work conditions. “287” (dir: John McRae, prod. Ian Bradley, wri. John Mortimore): Enter “The Freak” (Maggie Kirkpatrick) with her trademark leather gloves in tow. Christine (Amanda Muggleton) is arrested while breaching parole, Lizzie (Sheila Florance) has a hangover and the search is on for a secret distillery in the prison. Burns (Collette Mann) plays bookie. “327” (dir. Juliana Focht, prod. John McRae, wri. Anne Lucas): The Freak uses intimidation when searching for her lost diaries. A deliberately lit fire finds The Freak and Smith trapped togther in the cells. The women are relocated to a men’s prison due to fire damage. “400” (dir. Mark DeFriest, prod. Lex Van Os, wri. Ian Smith): Hazel assists Jude to suicide and has to deal with the legal consequences of her actions. With assistance from The Freak, there’s moves for a new Top Dog following Smith’s abrupt departure. Cast includes Elspeth Ballantyne, Judith McGrath, Betty Bobbitt, Val Lehman, Amanda Muggleton and Jane Clifton. Introduced by Peter McTighe. PLEASE NOTE: date recorded is copyright year and usually preceeds the screening year.
